text.p: Following are some of the leading stories in Norwegian newspapers this morning.

-The public prosecutor of Nordland county, Geir Fornebo, has given up hope of having anti-whaling activist Paul Watson extradited from the Netherlands. Watson, leader of the Sea Shepherd anti-whaling group, has been sentenced in his absence to 120 days in prison for sinking a Norwegian whaling boat in 1992. But he has been in custody in a Dutch jail since April 3 and has soon in effect served his sentence while his extradition order is being considered by the Netherlands.
-Airlines accuse travel agencies of selling jackpot and other cheap-fare tickets beyond the deadline for such sales, leading to losses for the carriers.
-Most members of parliament are in favour of investing billions of crowns of wealth accumulated in the State Petroleum Fund in overseas stock markets and not just in overseas bonds.
-Nice summer weather is expected in southern Norway in the next few days after weeks of rain, but next week the weather is expected to get colder again.

-While some people wish to avoid the taxman, citizens in Longyear in the remote Arctic archipelago of Spitzbergen want a tax office to be established in their tiny town for the sake of local democracy.
-Branded-goods conglomerate Orkla is increasing its investments in the United States through Holberg Industries, in which Orkla controls 33 percent.
-Norway and the EU commission have apparently agreed on a compromise on the issue of possible European Union anti-dumping duty on imports of Norwegian salmon.
